sentence: The year 2014 started on a weak note for consumer staples companies with concerns over higher gas prices, delayed income tax refunds and higher payroll taxes.
Fears of another European recession and difficult operating conditions in some Asian countries like China also added to the woes.
Extreme weather conditions affected almost all the consumer staples companies in the first three months of 2014.
Though weather improved in the second quarter and the labor market conditions started improving as well, the overall environment remained weak due to lower consumer demand.

Lackluster top-line growth, lower unit volumes as well as currency headwinds have been a drag on the results of consumer staples companies like The Procter & Gamble Co. (PG), Mondelez International, Inc. (MDLZ) and Kellogg Co. (K) in the first half of 2014 and have led many of them to provide a weak 2014 outlook.
(Read: Can a Great Holiday Season Rally these Retail ETFs? )
However, there have been some companies which managed to increase their earnings solely with the help of cost control, inorganic growth and share buybacks.

For example, soda giants The Coca-Cola Company (KO), PepsiCo, Inc. (PEP) and Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc. (DPS) have outperformed expectations in the first half of 2014 driven by aggressive marketing initiatives, cost containment and improved productivity.
A sequential improvement in beverage volumes in the second quarter of 2014 was the highlight of the quarter, impressing investors.
Buoyed by the strong performance in the second quarter, Dr Pepper Snapple and Pepsi raised their earnings outlook for 2014.
Food company McCormick & Co., Inc. (MKC) has also been benefiting from significant cost savings and share buybacks.
The company has also raised its fiscal year earnings forecast on the back of solid fundamentals.
Also, stock prices in the sector have done well lately (consumer staples have outperformed the broader S&P 500 index year to date), but many of the challenges still linger.

(Read: 3 Best Performing ETFs of the Third Quarter )

Given the defensive nature of this sector, it will outperform when equity markets are more bearish and underperform when bullish.
The ups and downs of the sector due to the U.S. and global exposure can be played with a wide array of ETFs (see all here ).
Launched on December 16, 1998, XLP seeks investment results corresponding to the S&P Consumer Staples Select Sector Index.

This fund consists of 41 companies that manufacture and sell a range of branded consumer packaged goods, with the top three holdings being The Procter & Gamble Co. (PG), Coca-Cola and Philip Morris International Inc (PM).
The fund's expense ratio is 0.16% and it has a dividend yield of 2.49%.
XLP has about $7.9 billion in assets under management as of October 13, 2013.
Initiated on January 26, 2004, VDC tracks the performance of the MSCI US Investable Market Consumer Staples 25/50 Index.
It measures the investment return of large-, mid-, and small-cap U.S. stocks in the consumer staples sector.
The fund has a total of 101 stocks, with the top three holdings being Procter & Gamble, Coca-Cola and PepsiCo.
It charges 0.14% in expense ratio, while the yield is 2.05% as of now.
VDC has managed to attract $2.2 billion in assets under management till September 30, 2014.
FXG, launched on May 8, 2007, follows the equity index called StrataQuant Consumer Staples Index.
FXG is made up of 37 consumer staples securities, with top holdings being The Kroger Co. (KR), Pilgrim's Pride Corporation (PPC) and Constellation Brands, Inc. (STZ).
The fund's expense ratio is 0.70% and the dividend yield is 1.34%, while it has $1.5 billion in assets under management as of October 13, 2013.
Launched on November 1, 2006, RHS seeks investment results corresponding to the S&P 500 Equal Weight Index Consumer Staples.
This is an equal-weighted fund and constitutes 40 stocks, with the top holdings being Clorox Co. (CLX), Altria Group, Inc. (MO) and Keurig Green Mountain Inc. (GMCR).
The fund's expense ratio is 0.40% and it has a dividend yield of 1.84%.
RHS has about $158.7 million in assets under management as of October 14, 2014.
FSTA, launched on October 21, 2013, follows the MSCI USA IMI Consumer Staples Index.
It comprises 99 stocks, with top holdings being Procter & Gamble, Coca-Cola and PepsiCo.
The fund's expense ratio is 0.12% and the dividend yield is 2.17%.
FSTA has about $120.3 million in assets under management as of September 30, 2014.
